channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Cities Say They Want Federal Agents Fighting Crime, Not Protesters
item.description: Rejecting the deployment of camouflaged federal agents, big-city mayors said the Trump administration should use its resources to help tackle problems like gun violence.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar, Charlie Savage and John Eligon
item.category: Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives
item.media:credit: Pat Nabong/Chicago Sun-Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mayor Lori Lightfoot of Chicago speaking last week. She and other mayors have spoken out against any plan to deploy anonymous federal officers to their cities.

item.title: The Virus Found a Crowded Houston Neighborhood, Sparing One Nearby
item.description: Two adjacent communities underscore the starkly divergent ways in which the coronavirus outbreak in Texas has attacked daily life.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Michael Starghill Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents in the spacious homes of Bellaire, Texas, have largely avoided the coronavirus. But the virus has spread considerably in Gulfton, an adjacent community in Houston where people are packed into apartments.

item.title: Minneapolis Police Experience Surge of Departures in Aftermath of George Floyd Protests
item.description: The retention and recruitment problems that many police departments have experienced in recent years are especially pronounced after four Minneapolis officers were charged with Mr. Floyd’s death.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Andrea Ellen Reed for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It’s almost like a nuclear bomb hit the city, and the people who didn’t perish are standing around,” Officer Rich Walker Sr., a 16-year Minneapolis police veteran and union official, said of the mood within the department.

item.title: Andrew Gillum and the Long Shadow of the Florida Governor’s Race
item.description: The magnetic former Democratic nominee for Florida governor went from being a breakout political star to checking into rehab.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:description: Andrew Gillum lost the Florida governor’s race in 2018. He then threw himself into growing a voter-registration organization, fund-raising for the Democratic Party and commentating for CNN.

item.title: The Pandemic Isn’t Bringing Back Factory Jobs, at Least Not Yet
item.description: It’s a moment of reckoning for global supply chains. But that doesn’t mean companies are flocking back to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: “The global pandemic has proven once and for all that to be a strong nation, America must be a manufacturing nation,” President Trump said at a Ford factory in Ypsilanti, Mich., in May.

item.title: Army Soldier Sentenced to 3 Years in Accident That Killed West Point Cadet
item.description: Staff Sgt. Ladonies P. Strong, who was convicted of negligent homicide, was behind the wheel of a truck that overturned last year, killing one and injuring more than 20.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:description: A portrait of Christopher Morgan, who was killed in an accident in June 2019, on a chair beside graduating classmates last month.

item.title: 14 People Are Shot Near Chicago Funeral Home
item.description: The shooting comes during a dispute between Mayor Lori Lightfoot and President Trump, who had said he would send federal agents to the city as it contends with violence.
item.dc:creator: Robert Chiarito and Will Wright
item.media:credit: Tyler Lariviere/Chicago Sun-Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Police officers investigated the scene where 14 people were shot in the Gresham neighborhood of Chicago on Tuesday.

item.title: Las Vegas Man Accused of ‘Thrill Killing’ of a Homeless Man
item.description: The police said Noah Green had later shot another man and had videos of both attacks on his cellphone.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:description: “We believe that we have taken a very dangerous person off of the streets,” Lt. Raymond Spencer of the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police said at a news conference on Monday.

item.title: Homeland Security Leaders on Defensive Amid Calls to Withdraw From Portland
item.description: The department’s acting secretary met with reporters and blamed local Oregon officials amid criticism that he has gone too far to suppress protests in Portland.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Chad Wolf, the acting homeland security secretary, defended agents who have been accused of placing protesters in unmarked vans without telling them where they are going.

item.title: Powerful Ohio Republican Is Arrested in $60 Million Corruption Scheme
item.description: The House speaker was connected with a conspiracy to enact a $1.3 billion bailout of an energy company, the F.B.I. said.
item.dc:creator: Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
item.media:description: Larry Householder, the Republican speaker of Ohio’s House of Representatives.

item.title: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Embraces Republican Ted Yoho's Insult
item.description: Representative Ted Yoho reportedly approached Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez on the steps of the Capitol, calling her “disgusting” for her policies and uttering a pair of expletives.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez in Queens last month. She arrived on Capitol Hill in 2019 with an outsize profile and has frequently been a target of derision by white Republican men.

item.title: As Trump Pushes Into Portland, His Campaign Ads Turn Darker
item.description: The Trump campaign is spending millions on ads that promote a dark and exaggerated portrayal of Democratic-led cities, a tactic that reinforces his “law and order’’ campaign message.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman, Nick Corasaniti and Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents clashed with protesters in Portland, Ore., on Tuesday. President Trump has strained to tie images of unrest in American cities to his Democratic opponent, Joseph R. Biden Jr.

item.title: Trump Campaign Ads Depict His Own Lawless Dystopia
item.description: For the past three weeks, the Trump campaign has been spending tens of millions of dollars on ads depicting a protest movement out of control, both to stoke fear among his base and rationalize his deployment decisions.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti

item.title: Republicans Heap Criticism on Liz Cheney, Calling Her Disloyal to Trump
item.description: In an extraordinary intraparty airing of grievances, House Republicans lashed out at their third-ranking leader, who has sometimes broken with the president but until now escaped the ire of his closest allies.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:description: Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming is one of the most conservative Republicans in the House.

item.title: Police Find Body in Building Burned Down During George Floyd Protests
item.description: The body was found at the site of a Minneapolis pawnshop that was set on fire just days after the death of Mr. Floyd.
item.dc:creator: Allyson Waller
item.category: Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives
item.media:description: A Minneapolis pawnshop burning in late May during protests that followed the death of George Floyd.

item.title: When John Lewis Cosplayed at Comic-Con as His Younger Self
item.description: For several years, Mr. Lewis would lead a group of children in a march across the San Diego Convention Center.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: Carlos Gonzalez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative John Lewis during a return visit to Comic-Con in San Diego in 2016. Andrew Aydin, his aide and co-author, is at right.

item.title: States Must Standardize Coronavirus Data, Former C.D.C. Director Says
item.description: Dr. Thomas Frieden proposed uniform reporting guidelines for states. Experts said the C.D.C. should have done it months ago.
item.dc:creator: Donald G. McNeil Jr.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Kevin D. Liles for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We have a real vacuum of leadership at the national level,” said Dr. Thomas Frieden, who led the C.D.C. from 2009 to 2017.

item.title: After Nightly Protest in Portland, Cleanup Crews Assess the Damage
item.description: “Every morning, time to sweep up the mess,” said a resident of Portland, Ore., who was clearing away protest debris on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: A fire where federal agents clashed with protesters in Portland, Ore., on Tuesday.

item.title: Senate Kills Broad Curbs on Military Gear for Police, Thwarting Push to Demilitarize
item.description: The Senate adopted a narrower proposal to limit the transfer of some military equipment to local police departments, but data shows that such restrictions have done little to reduce the flow.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: State police officers dispersing a protest after the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis in May.

item.title: Whole Foods Punished Workers for Black Lives Matter Masks, Suit Says
item.description: Over a dozen workers at Whole Foods stores in four states claim in a class-action lawsuit that the company retaliated against them for wearing the movement’s apparel.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: Protesters gathered outside a Whole Foods store in Cambridge, Mass., last month.

item.title: Apple, Facing Pressure on Climate, Says It'll Go Carbon-Neutral
item.description: Apple said on Tuesday its devices would be carbon-neutral by 2030, making it the latest tech giant to ramp up voluntary climate targets.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Veronica Penney
item.media:description: A new Apple store in Beijing this month.

item.title: Trump Seeks to Stop Counting Unauthorized Immigrants in Drawing House Districts
item.description: Critics described the move as unconstitutional and a transparent attempt to help Republicans.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Trump, in a statement, accused “the radical left” of trying to “conceal the number of illegal aliens in our country.”

item.title: Americans Hunker Down, Threatening the Self-Storage Industry
item.description: What once seemed like one of the few recession-proof parts of commercial real estate looks as vulnerable as many other businesses.
item.dc:creator: Tom Acitelli
item.media:credit: Devin Oktar Yalkin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Self-storage rates have fallen in the pandemic as the industry grapples with fewer moves and new entrants like MakeSpace.

item.title: A Kangaroo Got Loose in Florida. Now Its Owner May Face Charges.
item.description: The kangaroo, named Jack, was corralled by the police last week after he was spotted hopping down a street in Fort Lauderdale.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Joe Cavaretta/South Florida Sun-Sentinel, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jack the kangaroo in a stall at police headquarters in Ft. Lauderdale, Fla., on Thursday.

item.title: Some Vaccine Makers Say They Plan to Profit From Coronavirus Vaccine
item.description: Moderna, which is receiving $483 million from the U.S. government, told lawmakers it would not sell its vaccine at cost. Pfizer has said it would also profit, but has so far taken no government money.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
item.category: House Committee on Energy and Commerce
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.media:description: The headquarters of the biotechnology company Moderna Therapeutics in Cambridge, Mass.

item.title: Trump’s Tulsa Rally Drew Sparse Crowd, but It Cost $2.2 Million
item.description: New campaign filings show that President Trump’s campaign paid more than $2.2 million for the event, which last month had a lower-than-expected turnout that disappointed his campaign.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Rachel Shorey
item.media:description: President Trump speaking at his Make America Great Again rally in Tulsa, Okla., on June 20.

item.title: U.S. Accuses Hackers of Trying to Steal Coronavirus Vaccine Data for China
item.description: Two suspects in China targeted companies working on vaccines as part of a broader cybertheft campaign to enrich themselves and aid the Chinese government, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China
item.media:description: Researchers in China are trying to develop their own coronavirus vaccine.

item.title: Coronavirus Relief Bill: Republicans Eye Stimulus Checks and Billions for Schools
item.description: Several Senate Republicans, in a closed-door lunch, railed against the prospect of another sweeping spending bill.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane and Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m going to introduce a bill in the next few days that is a starting place that enjoys fairly significant support among Republican senators, probably not everyone,” Senator Mitch McConnell said.

item.title: When the Bake Sale Goes Global, Millions Are Raised to Fight Injustice
item.description: Online sales have become blockbuster events as long-sidelined pastry chefs lead a charge toward activism.
item.dc:creator: Julia Moskin
item.media:credit: Rozette Rago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mallory Cayon, a pastry chef in Los Angeles who participated in Pies For Justice. Although pastry is still dismissed as “women’s work” in some professional kitchens, she says that respect for the field is rising.

item.title: What Do Sweden and Mexico Have in Common? A Feminist Foreign Policy
item.description: Six years after Sweden adopted a feminist foreign policy, several other countries are following its lead, raising pressure on the U.S. to do the same.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta

item.title: Patient, Can You Spare a Dime?
item.description: Hospitals are increasingly soliciting donations from patients, and the patients don’t much like it, a new survey finds.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.category: Journal of the American Medical Assn

item.title: Portland Protest Photos: Federal Forces Clash with Demonstrators
item.description: Thousands gathered downtown to protest as the conflict with law enforcement intensified overnight.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times and Mason Trinca
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest at the U.S. District Court building in Portland, Ore., on Tuesday morning. The city has had protests for 54 consecutive days.

item.title: C.D.C. Data Shows U.S. Coronavirus Infections Much Higher Than Reported
item.description: Data from antibody tests in 10 different cities and states indicate that many people with no symptoms may be spreading the virus.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Journal of the American Medical Assn
item.media:description: Foot traffic in Manhattan last week. Even the hardest hit areas of the U.S., like New York City, are far from numbers approaching herd immunity.

item.title: After Death of John Lewis, Democrats Renew Push for Voting Rights Law
item.description: Democrats and activists who have long sought to update the Voting Rights Act say the proper way to honor the fallen civil rights icon is to pass it and name it in his honor. Republicans are opposed.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative John Lewis and other House Democrats arriving at a news conference about voting rights outside the Capitol last year.

item.title: Chaotic Scenes in Portland as Backlash to Federal Deployment Grows
item.description: The street demonstrations that have shuddered through Portland for 54 consecutive nights have drawn out a complicated mix of emotions and grievances.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents clashed with protesters early Tuesday morning.

item.title: Coronavirus in California: Newsom Issues New Guidelines for Salon Services
item.description: Tuesday: Learning to live with the pandemic continues to be a consuming challenge. Also: An effort to destigmatize mental health care.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: Anthony Milinkovich waited for his turn for a haircut, outside George's Barber Shop last week in San Pedro.

item.title: Biden Announces a $775 Billion Plan for Caregivers Amid Coronavirus
item.description: President Trump spoke at his first coronavirus task force briefing since April, a concession to his diminished standing in his re-election effort. New filings revealed his campaign paid $4 million to Trump businesses and spent more than $2 million on his Tulsa rally, which drew few attendees.

item.title: Teachers Push Back on Reopening in Florida
item.description: Educators unions sue Ron DeSantis, and Congress debates virus aid: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Climate Change Poses ‘Systemic Threat’ to the Economy, Big Investors Warn
item.description: Financial regulators should act to avoid economic disaster, according to a letter from pension funds and other investors representing almost $1 trillion in assets.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:description: A letter signed by executives from pension plans and other major investors warned the Federal Reserve and other agencies of the financial risks of climate change.

item.title: Trump’s Threat of Force
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Portland Monday night.

item.title: Biden Announces $775 Billion Plan to Help Working Parents and Caregivers
item.description: In a speech in Delaware, Joseph R. Biden Jr. outlined proposals covering care for small children, older adults and family members with disabilities.
item.dc:creator: Claire Cain Miller, Shane Goldmacher and Thomas Kaplan
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Professional caregivers, Joseph R. Biden Jr. said in a speech on Tuesday in New Castle, Del., “are too often underpaid, unseen and undervalued.”

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates
item.description: More than 20,000 members of the U.S. military have contracted the virus, and the infection rate has soared recently. Major security flaws were found in a South Korean quarantine app.

item.title: Facing ‘a Lot of Blowback,’ Trump’s Surgeon General Steps Up
item.description: Dr. Jerome Adams is poised to take on a more prominent role in the Trump administration’s coronavirus response. Are his bosses willing to back him?
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Noah Weiland
item.media:description: “I have a powerful opportunity to have an influence in this administration, and I feel like I need to be at the table,” said Dr. Jerome Adams, the surgeon general.

item.title: Why High Voter Turnout and Record Fund-Raising is Giving Democrats Hope for November
item.description: Despite a disjointed primary season and the challenges of holding elections during a pandemic, the party is seeing a surge in energy among voters.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Isabella Grullón Paz
item.media:credit: Nitashia Johnson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Texans showed up to vote in Dallas in the primary runoff elections on July 14.

item.title: New Emails Show How Energy Industry Moved Fast to Undo Curbs
item.description: The messages, made public in a lawsuit, suggest the E.P.A. rescinded a requirement on methane at the behest of an executive just weeks after President Trump took office.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Pump jacks in Midland, Texas.

item.title: Worried About Crowded Flights? Know Where Your Airline Stands
item.description: Whether your flight will be jammed with passengers, or have enough empty seats to soothe virus-fearing travelers, really depends on the airline.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac
item.media:description: An American Airlines flight from Seattle to Chicago on July 16.
